channel.title: Comments on: Getting started with node.js

item.content:encoded: It happens that smashing magazine published an article on node and mongo today. Good for getting started

item.title: By: Nick Wall
item.dc:creator: Nick Wall
item.description:
<p>I've been using Angular for a while now. In a nutshell: all your client side code is in your client side "models" and "controllers" and you have your "directives" generate the html. But you end up doing no DOM manipulation, Angular will look after the 2 way data binding (there are perf' issues you can address with 1 way binding, e.g. once.js). I have been working on a MVV* app that has been in production now for around 2.5 yrs, mountains of spaghetti code keeping DOM and REST "models" in sync, nightmare. An MVV* framework would have made it way, way simpler...and testable. On current project we are using it...so much nicer. Object.observe() will soon be with us! http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/es7/observe/</p>
<p>Anyway, always good to read your articles, so will follow with great interest.</p>
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been using Angular for a while now. In a nutshell: all your client side code is in your client side "models" and "controllers" and you have your "directives" generate the html. But you end up doing no DOM manipulation, Angular will look after the 2 way data binding (there are perf’ issues you can address with 1 way binding, e.g. once.js). I have been working on a MVV* app that has been in production now for around 2.5 yrs, mountains of spaghetti code keeping DOM and REST "models" in sync, nightmare. An MVV* framework would have made it way, way simpler…and testable. On current project we are using it…so much nicer. Object.observe() will soon be with us! http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/es7/observe/

Anyway, always good to read your articles, so will follow with great interest.

item.title: By: Mark Roden
item.dc:creator: Mark Roden
item.description:
<p>". I mean if I can do it then so can you." - there you go overestimating the abilities of the rest of us again :)</p>
<p>Thank you so much for sharing - glad you have the opportunity to branch out into node.js - looks very interesting to me and I look forward to reading more :)</p>
item.content:encoded:
". I mean if I can do it then so can you." – there you go overestimating the abilities of the rest of us again ðŸ™‚
